newsitem.title: JAPAN: Softbank to launch online computer magazine.
newsitem.headline: Softbank to launch online computer magazine.

text.p: Japan's agressively expanding software and publishing house Softbank Corp said on Thursday it would launch an Internet magazine specialising in computers.
The service, to be launched on September 1, will be a Japanese version of "ZDNet," an online information service in English offered by Ziff-Davis Inc, a unit of Softbank.
"I will make it the number one contents site in Japan," Softbank president Masayoshi Son told a news conference.
The Japanese magazine will rely on advertisements for revenue.
The Japanese version of ZDNet's "PC Magazine Online" will be carried on the magazine as well as other computer-related news, domestic and foreign, which will be updated daily.
Softbank will initially aim for 10 million page views of ZDNet Japan each month and hopes for 50 million views a month within a year of the launch, the company said.
The English language ZDNet serves about three million users and 100 million pages are viewed each month, Softbank said.

Softbank is aiming Yahoo!Japan, a service the company jointly started with Yahoo Inc of the United States last year, at general Internet users while it sees ZDNet Japan as a service for computer enthusiasts.
Yahoo!Japan,is a Japanese-language Internet service, currently serves one million users, and four million pages are viewed each day, Softbank said.
Softbank also said that Japan's advertising market on the Internet would grow to 40 billion yen ($350 million) by 2000, from 1.6 billion yen ($14.0 million) in 1996.

On Wednesday, the Japanese business daily Nihon Keizai Shimbun said that Softbank planned to set up a 10 billion yen ($87.7 million) to 20 billion yen ($175 million) investment partnership fund early next month to help television production firms.
The fund is intended to help develop programming for Softbank's JSkyB satellite broadcasting venture with News Corp Ltd, Sony Corp and the Fuji Television Network.

Also on Wednesday, a Japanese unit of Internet Security Systems Inc of the United States said that it planned to set up a joint venture with Softbank to sell software for computer network security in Japan. ($1=114 yen)
